background: A man needs to meet his daily iron and calcium requirements by taking pills from two different supplements, A and B, which contain varying amounts of iron and calcium.
constraints: Number of supplement A pills is non-negative
Number of supplement B pills is non-negative
Total units of iron from pills must be at least IronReq
Total units of calcium from pills must be at least CalciumReq
objective: Minimize the total cost of purchasing pills of supplement A and B
description: A man takes two supplements to get his daily iron and calcium requirements. A pill of supplement A has \param{IronA} units of iron and \param{CalciumA} units of calcium. A pill of supplement B contains \param{IronB} units of iron and \param{CalciumB} units of calcium. The man needs a minimum of \param{IronReq} units of iron and \param{CalciumReq} units of calcium per day. If the cost per pill of supplement A is $\param{CostA} and the cost per pill of supplement B is $\param{CostB}, how many of each should he buy to minimize costs?

parameters.definition: Units of iron in supplement A
Units of calcium in supplement A
Units of iron in supplement B
Units of calcium in supplement B
Cost per pill of supplement A
Cost per pill of supplement B
